title: The tragedy of the commons is a false and dangerous myth | Aeon Essays

last_post.content:
The so-called Tragedy of the Commons was basically white nationalist simplistic bullshit.

Great article on Elinor Ostrom and her work on commons:

https://aeon.co/essays/the-tragedy-of-the-commons-is-a-false-and-dangerous-myth

Huh.

Consumer Reports (CR) has released a mobile app (iOS, Android on the way) that shows what data companies collect about you, then allows you to have CR get the data deleted:

https://www.permissionslipcr.com

Essentially, CR will act as the data ombudsman for anyone who asks them to. I love it.

CR is a non-profit that accepts no advertising or corporate sponsorship, and they have a great reputation. It's a superb choice to take on the data capitalists.

#privacy

https://blog.archive.org/2023/01/29/a-calculated-move-calculators-now-emulated-at-internet-archive/

..which is actually a stealth request that people consider joining the MAME Artwork efforts, which allow beautiful renderings of machines to be clickable on machines. It's more in the Art than Programming sphere, and it would be great if more people joined it.

"database publishing" is really hard to indie publishers without a strong technical background.

But I want to see a million small weird libraries and collections exist.

Wrote up my thoughts here: https://tomcritchlow.com/2023/01/27/small-databases/

title: ongoing by Tim Bray · Private and Public Mastodon

last_post.content:
People argue passionately about the importance of staying in control of the content they share here - this has been a key element of the ongoing debates around search and Mastodon/the Fediverse

Meanwhile, ActivityPub works by delivering a copy of everything you say to every server used by at least one of your followers - with no guarantees at all about what those many servers will then do with that data

Here's a more thoughtful related take on this from @timbray https://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/202x/2022/12/30/Mastodon-Privacy-and-Search

I designed the 12-bit rainbow palette for use on https://grid.iamkate.com. It consists of twelve colours chosen with consideration for how we perceive hue, chroma, and luminance. The palette uses a 12-bit colour depth, so each colour requires only four characters when specified as a hexadecimal colour code in a CSS or SVG file. For more details, see https://iamkate.com/data/12-bit-rainbow/

"Cistercian Numbers" are incredibly cool

It's a rare numeric system designed by 13th century monks

Each number is a based on a single vertical stick, with patterns you draw in all four quadrants off it -- top right, top left, bottom right, bottom left

A single glyph can represent a number from 1 to 9,999

It's in my recent weekly "Linkfest" newsletter, here: https://buttondown.email/clivethompson/archive/linkfest-3-cisterian-numbers-robots-that-hug-and/

Want to subscribe? Pay-what-you-want here: https://buttondown.email/clivethompson

I call it "The opposite of doomscrolling"

title: Episode 161 – A Chat With Matt Mullenweg - Hallway Chats

last_post.content:
Matt Muellenweg re-comits #Tumblr to support #ActivityPub & to join the #Fediverse:

"Tumblr is...not open source yet. But we’ve said it’s going to be & we’ve tried to make the data super open. So the API’s, you can put your Tumblr into WordPress very easily, you can export all your Tumblr content... then longer term, we want to support these new protocols like activity pub on top of… We’re gonna support #RSS so things are easy to get in and out."

https://hallwaychats.com/episodes/episode-161-a-chat-with-matt-mullenweg/

The more clearly toxic flipside is something I recently wrote about concerning Elon Musk's boast that Twitter is an extremely effective digital outrage engine: https://fediscience.org/@ct_bergstrom/109705608811212373

But the thing is, it's not just the algorithms that make the contemporary internet such fertile ground for misinformation, disinformation, polarization, and toxicity. They almost certainly contribute, but it's not safe to assume that if we got rid of engagement-maximizing algorithms, these problems would go away.

In a new preprint, Henry Farrell and Cosma Shalizi present a thought experiment to illustrate the way in which the pathologies of our information ecosystem would arise from simple web 2.0 technology, without any algorithmic curation of content*. https://www.dropbox.com/s/pq089ti1kwauzso/acm-draft-2022-10-08.pdf?dl=0

*With platforms such as mastodon becoming prominent, this could soon become an empirically testable prediction–though I don't know how you deal with the selection bias problem resulting from who chooses to use these services.

title: Decoding the Hype About AI – The Markup

last_post.content:
ChatGPT is great at its job. But its job is to be a bullshit generator -- an automated creator of plausible lies.

"It is very good at being persuasive, but it's not trained to produce true statements," @randomwalker says in my latest newsletter.

https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/01/28/decoding-the-hype-about-ai

.@CMUDB Advanced DB Lecture #1: Andy's History of Databases: https://youtu.be/LWS8LEQAUVc?t=747

This is a quick crash course on the last 60 years of database systems starting with Integrated Data Store in 1964 and then going all the way to 2023.

"For everyone it’s different, but I do think that there’s something lost when you never take a leap. I feel like I see this when people climb the career ladder and just keep climbing. There must be some opportunity unlocked by taking a little bit of stability and salary that you could’ve gotten and doing something else with that energy."

Finally watched @cldellow's video introduction to his datasette-scraper plugin and it is a really compelling demo! https://youtu.be/zrSGnz7ErNI

The plugin turns Datasette into a full web scraping environment, with the ability to configure crawls, watch your crawl queue and extract data from crawled pages into separate SQLite tables

It's really impressive, and also provides a fascinating example of advanced Datasette UI customization by a plugin

More info on the plugin here: https://datasette.io/plugins/datasette-scraper

"Knud Rasmussen's life mission was to know the world as the Inuit did, to understand the patterns of their lives, to enter their realms of magic and shamanic power. With knowledge as his goal, cultural understanding the quest, he completely redefined the promise and potential of exploration, not to mention ethnography. "

In this powerful 2021 Long Now talk, Wade Davis reminds us what ethnography used to be, and ought to be again.

Preregistration:

Excellent new paper on preregistration that is firmly pro-preregistration but also discusses some of the recent critical work that's been done in this area (e.g., Devezer et al. 2021; Navarro, 2020; Szollosi et al., 2020; Szollosi & Donkin, 2021; Rubin, 2017, 2020). 👍

Hardwicke (@tomhardwicke) & Wagenmakers. (2023). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41562-022-01497-2

Preprint: https://osf.io/preprints/metaarxiv/d7bcu/

This is a huge deal:

The Open Collective Foundation has just announced: "OCF now offers employment options to initiative workers—with health insurance!" https://blog.opencollective.com/oc-news-nov-2021/

If your FLOSS project is on OpenCollective, you can hire a maintainer as an employee! With health insurance & 401(k)!

This is such a huge step forward for open source sustainability, in particular for projects with key contributors in the United States. Let's talk about why! https://www.harihareswara.net/sumana/2021/11/24/0

The Press needs to get a clue about social media!

They don't want to moderate discussions on their websites.

So they're shutting down discussions on their websites.

But what that does is move the discussion to a space (Twitter, Meta, etc.) that's largely unmoderated.

And on social media, few people are clicking to read the articles -- they're just seeing headlines.

What's the net effect? Big Social owns the news!

https://www.lohud.com/story/news/2023/01/28/usa-today-network-lohud-restricting-reader-comments-to-social-media/69851367007/
